As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity.

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity.

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I gen

That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Musi

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity.

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curricul

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity.

That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pu

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course ca

As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, becazu

As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of lear

I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 T

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity.

As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.

I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college

As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse th

As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn.

As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis

I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. W

I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that informa

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity.

With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I ne

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn.

I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me th

Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am.  Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writ

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writi

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, o

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artist

With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Th

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Tho

Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a

With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner.

I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I d

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one

That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important s

As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important subject. I believ

I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important subject. I believe that critical t

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important subject. I believe that critical thinking and creativity need to be

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important subject. I believe that critical thinking and creativity need to be the backbone of e

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important subject. I believe that critical thinking and creativity need to be the backbone of everything, and t

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

In my opinion, there is no single most important subject in school. Each subject works in conjunction with every other subject that a child learns. As time goes by, they begin to specialize in their area of interest. Further education tends to be more pointed, but it's a student's choice where that point lies on the spectrum. That being said, maybe the best a school can do for a student is to instill a desire to continue seeking knowledge. With that in mind, I would say that a good course track in critical thinking would be one of the most important things to teach students, but in conjunction with something that fosters creative curiosity. 
I think that the most important thing I learned in school was how to learn new things.
 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important subject. I believe that critical thinking and creativity need to be the backbone of everything, and those require att

 It wasn't until college that I actually took a course labeled as critical thinking, which was categorized as a philosophy credit. I believe that my educational experience would have been more satisfying had I been exposed to critical thinking, as an academic subject, much earlier in my career as a student. This would allow for a hands-on approach to the concept of thinking critically and understanding how to apply it.

Critical thinking, by itself, would not have been enough. I would also need to remember that it is the ideas that I generate myself, that are unique to me, that allow me to communicate who I am. Music and other arts have been stripped out of the curriculum of a lot of schools, leaving mainly creative writing as the only state sanctioned outlet for creativity. Creative pursuits should never be removed from the course catalog, because that is one of the foundations of learning how to learn. 
As I got older, I learned the power of being able to freely think through problems and challenges that I encounter.
 Today, I use critical thinking skills that I learned in college to help me traverse the massive amounts of information, and dis-information, that is available to me. With all that information sinking in, I need somewhere to put it. Music gives me that outlet, along with creative writing and some other, occasional, artistic pursuits. Those subjects have helped me to become a lifelong learner. I don't have all the answers, however I can always figure out where to go to get them.

In closing, I do not believe that there is any one, most important subject. I believe that critical thinking and creativity need to be the backbone of everything, and those require attention.
